manuscript.title: Muraqqaʿāt / مرقعات
manuscript.title_alt: Hasan Rıza Muraqqaʿātı — Meşk Albümü (Vol. II)
manuscript.calligrapher_note: Hasan Rıza (d. 1336/1920) was one of the most prolific and celebrated late Ottoman calligraphers of the Tanzimat–Meşrutiyet period. He studied under Sâmi Efendi (Mehmed Şefik, d. 1912), the dominant master of the period, and rose to prominence as a teacher and practitioner of nesih and sülüs scripts. He held positions at the Medresetü'l-Hattâtîn (School of Calligraphers, established 1914) and produced large numbers of calligraphic albums (muraqqaʿāt) as meşk (practice/teaching) specimens. His works are held in major Turkish collections including Süleymaniye, Türk ve İslam Eserleri Müzesi, and various private collections. The YEK catalogue records his name as 'Hasan Rıza' with the death date implied by the AH 1336 period. The ketebe inscriptions confirmed in the visual examination (p014 of yb_02788) and the consistent attribution in both matched volumes make the attribution firm.
manuscript.date_note: The date AH 1318 / 1900–01 CE appears in the YEK catalogue record and is confirmed by visual examination of p014, where a date inscription is legible at IIIF resolution. This is the later of the two albums in the matched pair: yb_02787 is dated AH 1315 / 1897–98 CE, three years earlier. The date difference suggests yb_02787 was the earlier teaching album and yb_02788 an expanded companion or continuation.
manuscript.format: Muraqqaʿāt / مرقعات — calligraphic teaching album with mixed battal and gel-git ebru margin papers
manuscript.format_note: A bound late Ottoman calligraphic teaching album (meşk muraqqaʿātı) of 10 folios (21 digitized pages), containing calligraphic exercises and specimen texts in nesih and sülüs scripts. The content includes huruf mufradāt (alphabetical letter exercises) and literary/hadith passages in alternating thuluth (large lines) and naskh (small lines). Each calligraphy panel is window-mounted (vassale) onto a sheet of ebru (marbled) paper, with a consistent multi-line cetvelli (ruled) framing system throughout. The defining decorative feature is the use of a DIFFERENT ebru paper for each calligraphy page, creating a program of maximum variety: at least 5 distinct ebru palettes and two ebru subtypes (battal and gel-git) across the examined pages. The album is the larger companion volume of a matched pair with yb_02787.
manuscript.script: Nesih (نسخ) and Sülüs (ثلث) — alternating large sülüs / thuluth lines with small nesih / naskh lines throughout

dimensions_mm.note: Outer dimensions 310×250 mm; text area 195×130 mm per YEK catalogue. Landscape-format album binding.

matched_pair.date_relationship: yb_02788 (AH 1318) is dated 3 years later than yb_02787 (AH 1315)
evidence_points: IDENTICAL binding: same red leather with same gold lattice trellis (salbek zerkâri) pattern, same diamond grid with quadrilobed floral nodes
IDENTICAL endpaper ebru: same red-green-grey battal ebru palette and pattern type, almost certainly from the same marbling session
Same calligrapher: both attributed to Hasan Rıza
Near-identical dates: AH 1318 (this album) vs. AH 1315 (yb_02787), 3 years apart
Identical decorative structure: murakkaat format, 5 columns, nesih/sülüs alternation, vassale mounting, ebru margins, multi-line cedvel
Shared closing text: both final pages contain the identical concluding prayer about al-salaf al-salihin
matched_pair.interpretation: A coordinated pair of late Ottoman calligraphic teaching albums (meşk muraqqaʿātı) by the same master. The identical bindings and endpapers confirm simultaneous or closely coordinated production. yb_02788 is the larger (10 leaves vs. 4 leaves) and later volume, suggesting it may represent an expanded curriculum or sequel.

manuscript.notes: YEK classification error: the catalogue lists this album under '012 / Kişilere ait bibliyografya ve kataloglar' (Personal bibliographies), which is clearly incorrect for a calligraphic teaching album. The matched companion yb_02787 is correctly classified under '740 / Çizgi sanatları ve dekoratif sanatlar'. This misclassification should be flagged for correction in the YEK catalogue. Catalogued by Halil İbrahim Salman. The album's mixed-ebru margin program — using a different paper for each calligraphy page across at least 5 distinct palettes and two subtypes (battal and gel-git) — is one of the most elaborate varied-ebru programs documented in the project corpus.

paper_decoration.summary: The decorative program of yb_02788 is organized around a systematically varied ebru (marbled paper) scheme, in which each calligraphy page receives a different ebru sheet — creating a chromatic sequence of maximum variety across the album. Three levels of decoration are present: (1) Binding exterior (p001): red leather cover with stamped gold lattice/trellis design — zerkâri, a salbek diamond grid with floral quadrilobed nodes at intersections and gold dots at centers, framed by multiple gold ruling lines. (2) Endpapers (p002): battal ebru (stone/spot marbled) in a red-coral, dark green, and cream-grey palette — classic large-droplet stone pattern. The same ebru is used for both inside cover doublures, confirming a single sheet was used for the endpaper program. (3) Calligraphy page margins (pp003–021): each of the examined calligraphy pages uses a DIFFERENT ebru paper for its outer margins, with the text panel window-mounted (vassale) into the ebru ground. Five distinct palettes and two ebru subtypes are confirmed across the seven examined pages: p003 (blue battal with white droplets), p008 (green-gold-brown gel-git / combed S-wave), p014 (red-green-grey battal), p018 (terracotta-brown battal with blue veins), p021 (purple-green battal with gold/yellow speckling). The remaining 14 unexamined pages likely contain further palettes. A consistent multi-line cedvel (ruled framing) system in gold, dark, and green lines frames each calligraphy panel throughout.
paper_decoration.distribution_notes: Zerkâri binding: front and back covers (pp001, last). Battal ebru (red-green-grey): inside front and back cover doublures (p002 and final endpaper). Mixed battal ebru: outer margins of all calligraphy pages; subtypes and palettes vary per page (see folio_analyses for per-page detail). Gel-git ebru: confirmed on p008 only among examined pages — additional gel-git examples may exist on unexamined pages. Multi-line cedvel framing: consistent throughout all calligraphy pages.

technique_terms.ottoman: battal ebru (taş ebru / leke ebru) — çeşitli renk paletleriyle; gel-git ebru (biz ile çekilmiş S-dalga deseni); vassale yöntemiyle monte edilmiş metin panelleri; altın cetvelli (çok çizgili çerçeve); zerkâri cilt kapağı (salbek kafes desen, lacivert içi çiçek düğümleriyle)
technique_terms.persian: abrī (ابری) — battal ve gel-git alt tipleri; vassāla (واساله) — pencere montaj tekniği; zarkārī (زرکاری) — gold-worked binding
technique_terms.arabic: kāġaz abrī (کاغذ ابری) — marbled paper; jadwal mudhahdhab (جدول مذهّب) — gold-ruled frame

catalogue_description.notes_field: Murakka album of calligraphic exercises and literary passages in naskh and thuluth scripts. 10 leaves with 5 text columns per page. Each calligraphy panel is vassale-mounted into ebru margin papers with elaborate multi-line cedvel framing. The calligrapher Hasan Rıza (d. AH 1336/1920) was a prominent late Ottoman calligrapher and student of Sami Efendi.
catalogue_description.notes_field_normalized: Nesih ve sülüs yazı türlerinde hat alıştırmaları ve edebi pasajlardan oluşan muraqqaʿāt albümü. Her sayfada 5 metin sütunu bulunan 10 yaprak. Her hat paneli, çok çizgili cedvel çerçeveleme ile ebrulu kâğıt zeminlere vassale tekniğiyle monte edilmiştir.
catalogue_description.notes_field_translation: A calligraphic album (muraqqaʿāt) of calligraphic exercises and literary passages in naskh and sülüs scripts. 10 leaves with 5 text columns per page. Each calligraphy panel is window-mounted (vassale) onto ebru paper with elaborate multi-line cedvel framing.
catalogue_description.source: YEK portal, genel_notlar field, record 346285, Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi — Yazma Bağışlar Koleksiyonu. Catalogued by Halil İbrahim Salman. All paper decoration observations derive from visual examination of IIIF images (7 of 21 pages).

key_indicators: Dated ketebe of Hasan Rıza (d. 1336/1920) at AH 1318 / 1900–01 CE places production in late Ottoman Istanbul with near-certainty
Hasan Rıza was a student of Sâmi Efendi and active in Istanbul's Medresetü'l-Hattâtîn — a firmly Istanbul-based calligraphic environment
The varied-ebru margin program, with multiple distinct palettes per album, reflects a well-resourced late Ottoman ebru atelier in Istanbul
The zerkâri salbek binding (gold lattice/trellis on red leather) is characteristic of late Ottoman luxury album bindings produced in Istanbul
The vassale mounting technique and multi-line cetvelli framing system are hallmarks of the Ottoman late-period murakkaʿāt tradition as practiced in Istanbul
cross_tradition_caveats: Only 7 of 21 pages examined: additional decoration types or palettes on the 14 unexamined pages cannot be ruled out
The identity of the ebru maker is unknown; the multi-palette mixed program implies a professional ebrici but cannot be attributed to a named workshop

YEK catalogue classification error (012 instead of 740) may indicate the record was processed by a non-specialist cataloguer, creating minor uncertainty about the completeness of the textual description

paper.color: Two paper types: (1) cream/off-white burnished âharlı paper for the calligraphy text panels; (2) ebru papers for margins — five distinct palettes confirmed on examined pages (see folio_analyses for detail). Endpaper ebru: red-coral, dark green, and cream-grey battal.
paper.preparation: The calligraphy panels are on âharlı (sized and burnished) cream paper, consistent with high-quality late Ottoman calligraphy paper. The ebru margin papers vary by page and represent different marbling sessions or trough batches. The gel-git ebru on p008 is clearly distinct in production technique from the battal ebru sheets used elsewhere.
paper.weight: Indeterminate from IIIF images. Standard Ottoman album weight expected for a 310×250 mm album.
paper.decoration: Ebru margin papers (battal and gel-git subtypes); zerkâri gold lattice binding. Multi-line cetvelli framing in gold, dark, and green lines on all calligraphy pages.
paper.paper_type: Eastern/Oriental âharlı paper for calligraphy panels; professionally marbled Ottoman ebru papers for margins and endpapers.

ruling.system: Consistent multi-line altın cetvelli (gold ruling) framing throughout the album, applying the same structural system to every calligraphy page.
ruling.description: Each calligraphy opening presents a layered framing system visible at IIIF resolution: (from outside in) the ebru outer margin paper; a multi-line gold cetvel system in gold, dark green/black, and green lines forming a 3-line nested frame; and the cream calligraphy text panel. The outer frame border (dış pervaz) is the ebru paper itself; the inner rules (iç pervaz) are the gold and coloured cetvels; the text panel is the innermost element. The seam of the vassale mounting (window cut in the ebru sheet) is clearly visible at the panel edge on examined pages. No koltuk (corner illumination) pieces are observed — the framing relies entirely on the cetvelli system for articulation.

binding.cover_description: Front and back covers in red leather with a stamped gold lattice/trellis (salbek zerkâri) design. The binding pattern consists of a continuous diamond grid with quadrilobed floral nodes at each intersection point and small gold dots at the center of each diamond. Multiple gold ruling frames border the design field. The binding is in excellent condition. Landscape format (horizontal orientation). Library accession labels ('Yazma Bağışlar 2788' and 'CDN 66') are affixed to the inside cover.
binding.cover_type: Deri cilt — red leather with gold lattice zerkâri (salbek kafes) and framing rules. Landscape format.
binding.notes: The binding design is IDENTICAL to the matched companion album yb_02787, confirming both volumes were produced as a coordinated set. The salbek kafes (diamond lattice) zerkâri is a standard late Ottoman luxury album binding type. The landscape (horizontal) format is appropriate for a multi-column calligraphic album.

codicology.format: Muraqqaʿāt — late Ottoman calligraphic teaching album (meşk muraqqaʿātı), 10 folios, 21 digitized pages, landscape format
codicology.condition_summary: Generally well preserved. The binding is in excellent condition. The ebru margin papers are vivid and legible. No catastrophic damage, missing leaves, or major repair campaigns visible in examined pages. Endpaper shows typical light library wear.

visual_confirmation.visual_evidence: p001: Red leather binding cover with gold lattice/trellis (zerkâri) pattern — diamond grid with floral quadrilobed nodes at intersections, gold dots at centers, framed by multiple gold ruling lines. Excellent condition. p002: Battal ebru doublure/endpaper in red-coral, dark green, and cream-grey palette. Classic large-droplet stone pattern. Library label 'Yazma Bağışlar 2788' and 'CDN 66' visible. p003: Blue battal ebru margins with white droplets — different palette from endpaper. Vassale-mounted calligraphy panel showing huruf mufradāt (Arabic alphabetical exercise) in alternating thuluth (large) and naskh (small) lines. Multi-line cedvel framing: gold, dark green/black, green lines. p008: Green-gold-brown gel-git (combed) ebru margins with flowing S-wave pattern — distinct subtype from battal on other pages. Same vassale and cedvel system. p014: Red-green-grey battal ebru margins (different palette again). Date inscription '1318' and ketebe/signature of Hasan Rıza legible. p018: Terracotta-brown battal ebru margins with distinctive blue veins through the brown-red stone pattern. p021 (last page): Purple-green battal ebru margins with gold/yellow speckling throughout. Closing prayer text. Each of the five calligraphy pages examined uses a different ebru paper — demonstrating a deliberately varied decorative program.
limitations: Only 7 of 21 pages examined (33% coverage). The 14 unexamined pages likely contain additional distinct ebru palettes not captured in this record.
IIIF resolution (2592x1944 px for a 310x250 mm album) is moderate — adequate for ebru identification but fine cedvel details and any possible zerefşân elements would benefit from higher resolution.
YEK catalogue classification error (012 / Bibliyografya vs. correct 740) noted; this does not affect decoration analysis but may affect future discoverability.
IIIF files were initially downloaded to a Playwright temp directory; copies required to corpus/iiif/ with standardized underscore naming.

elements.motif: Red leather binding with gold lattice zerkâri (salbek kafes) — front cover
elements.description: The front cover is red leather with a stamped gold lattice/trellis (zerkâri) pattern. The design consists of a continuous diamond grid with quadrilobed floral nodes at each grid intersection and small gold dots at the center of each diamond cell. Multiple gold ruling frames border the design field at the cover edge. The album is in landscape (horizontal) format. Two library accession labels are affixed ('Yazma Bağışlar 2788' and 'CDN 66'). Binding is in excellent condition with minimal wear.

folio_analyses.notes: The binding design is IDENTICAL to the matched companion volume yb_02787, confirming coordinated production. The salbek kafes (diamond lattice) zerkâri type is characteristic of late Ottoman luxury album bindings of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

folio_analyses.folio: Inside cover spread — battal ebru endpapers (IIIF p002)

elements.motif: Battal ebru doublure/endpaper — red-coral, dark green, cream-grey palette
elements.description: The inside front cover and first endpaper are covered with battal ebru (stone/spot marbled) paper in a three-color palette of red-coral, dark green, and cream-grey. The pattern shows classic large-droplet stone marbling with organic blob shapes of the three colors distributed evenly across the surface. The palette is warm and relatively saturated. Library accession label 'Yazma Bağışlar 2788' and the label 'CDN 66' are visible on the inside cover. The same palette and pattern type appears on the matched companion yb_02787, and is almost certainly from the same marbling session or workshop.
elements.location: Inside front cover doublure and first endpaper

folio_analyses.notes: The battal ebru endpaper palette (red-coral, dark green, cream-grey) is identical in color scheme and pattern character to the endpapers of yb_02787. This shared endpaper is the strongest single piece of material evidence linking the two albums as a coordinated pair.

folio_analyses.folio: First calligraphy page — blue battal ebru margins (IIIF p003)

elements.motif: Blue battal ebru — outer margin, both pages
elements.description: The outer margin of the calligraphy opening at p003 is covered with battal ebru in a blue and white palette. The pattern shows light blue ground with white stone spots — a two-color battal ebru subtype in a cool, restrained palette distinct from the warm red-green endpaper ebru.

elements.motif: Multi-line cetvelli framing — gold, dark, green ruling lines
elements.description: Between the blue battal ebru outer margin and the cream calligraphy text panel, a multi-line cedvel framing system is visible: gold ruling lines, dark green/black lines, and green lines in a nested frame of at least three lines. The vassale seam (joint between ebru margin and mounted text panel) is clearly visible.

elements.motif: Calligraphy panel — huruf mufradāt (Arabic letter exercises) in sülüs and nesih
elements.description: Vassale-mounted calligraphy panel on cream âharlı paper showing huruf mufradāt (Arabic alphabetical letter exercises) in alternating thuluth (large lines) and naskh (small lines). The content appears to be a systematic letter-form practice sequence.

folio_analyses.notes: Page 3 opens the calligraphic body of the album with the first distinct ebru palette — blue and white battal. The contrast with the warm red-green endpaper ebru is deliberate and demonstrates the album's varied-palette design philosophy from the outset.

folio_analyses.folio: Calligraphy page — green-gold gel-git ebru margins (IIIF p008)

elements.description: The outer margin at p008 shows a gel-git (come-go) ebru in a palette of green, gold/ochre, and brown. The gel-git subtype is produced by drawing a single stylus (biz) back and forth through pigment floated on a size, creating flowing organic S-curves. This is clearly distinct from the battal (stone/spot) ebru used on other pages, both in technique and visual character. The S-wave pattern is legible at IIIF resolution.

elements.motif: Multi-line cetvelli framing — same system as throughout
elements.description: Same multi-line gold, dark, and green cedvel system as on other pages. Vassale seam visible.

elements.motif: Calligraphy panel — Arabic letter combinations in sülüs and nesih
elements.description: Vassale-mounted panel with Arabic letter combinations ('ayn-lam-ba etc.) in alternating sülüs and nesih lines — continuing the meşk (teaching) curriculum sequence.

folio_analyses.notes: The gel-git ebru on p008 is the only confirmed gel-git example among the examined pages of yb_02788. It introduces a qualitatively different ebru subtype into the margin program, demonstrating the album's access to more than one marbling technique. The gel-git example in the companion album yb_02787 (p007, the most colorful ebru in the paired set) suggests both albums drew from the same well-stocked ebru atelier.

folio_analyses.folio: Calligraphy page with ketebe — red-green-grey battal ebru margins (IIIF p014)

elements.description: The outer margin at p014 is battal ebru in a three-color red, green, and grey palette — similar in hue range to the endpaper ebru but with different execution, demonstrating that the endpaper and margin papers, while sharing a palette family, are distinct sheets.

elements.motif: Date inscription '1318' and ketebe of Hasan Rıza
elements.description: The calligraphy panel at p014 includes a legible date inscription reading '1318' (AH) and an apparent ketebe (colophon) inscription by Hasan Rıza. This is the primary date evidence confirming the AH 1318 / 1900–01 CE production date.

folio_analyses.notes: Page 14 provides the key date evidence (AH 1318) and calligrapher identification (Hasan Rıza ketebe), making it the most informationally significant page in the album.

folio_analyses.folio: Calligraphy page — terracotta-brown battal ebru with blue veins (IIIF p018)

elements.motif: Terracotta-brown battal ebru with blue veins — outer margin
elements.description: The outer margin at p018 shows battal ebru in a distinctive terracotta/brown palette with blue veins running through the brown-red stone pattern. This combination of warm terracotta and cool blue within a single battal sheet is a distinctive palette not repeated in the other examined pages.

elements.motif: Calligraphy panel — literary/hadith text referencing Ibn Hilāl
elements.description: The text panel includes a reference to 'Ibn Hilāl rahimahu Allāh', likely a quotation from a literary or hadith source, in alternating sülüs and nesih.

folio_analyses.notes: The terracotta-blue palette at p018 is the fourth distinct battal ebru palette in the examined pages (endpaper being red-green-grey, p003 blue-white, p014 red-green-grey variant), demonstrating the programmatic variety of the album's margin papers.

folio_analyses.folio: Final page — purple-green battal ebru with gold speckling (IIIF p021)

elements.motif: Purple-green battal ebru with gold/yellow speckling — outer margin
elements.description: The outer margin at p021 (the final calligraphy page) shows battal ebru in a purple and green palette with gold or yellow speckling distributed throughout the surface. The gold/yellow speckling over the battal ebru pattern is unusual and may indicate the addition of a metallic element to the marbling trough, or a secondary application of gold pigment over the completed ebru sheet. This is the most decoratively elaborate of the examined margin papers.

elements.motif: Closing prayer text — matching yb_02787 p009
elements.description: The final page text contains the closing prayer about al-salaf al-ṣāliḥīn (the pious ancestors), the same concluding text that appears on the final page of the companion album yb_02787. This shared closing formula is the textual confirmation of the matched pair relationship.

folio_analyses.notes: The purple-green battal with gold/yellow speckling on the final page provides a visually climactic close to the album's varied-palette ebru program. The gold speckling element is unusual in a purely marbled context and deserves physical examination to confirm its technique. The shared closing text with yb_02787 (p009) is the strongest textual evidence for the matched pair identification.

terms_used.english: Muraqqaʿāt: a bound Ottoman calligraphic album, typically containing kıtʿa (calligraphic specimen sheets) in one or more scripts. This album is specifically a meşk muraqqaʿātı (teaching/practice album), the type used to instruct students in correct letter-forms and to demonstrate the master's technique.

Meşk: calligraphic practice and teaching. A meşk muraqqaʿātı is a teaching album in which the master calligrapher demonstrates letter forms, ligatures, and complete texts as models for students. The huruf mufradāt (individual letters) and the systematic progression of the content in yb_02788 are characteristic of the meşk genre.

terms_used.ottoman: huruf mufradāt / harflerin ayrı ayrı yazılması
terms_used.english: Huruf mufradāt: individual Arabic letters written in isolation as calligraphic exercises — the foundational practice of the meşk curriculum. Observed on p003 of this album.

Battal ebru: stone or spot marbling — the most basic marbling technique, producing irregular organic blob shapes by floating pigments on a carrageenan (or gum tragacanth) size without combing or manipulation. Yields an organic, spotted pattern. The dominant ebru subtype in this album.

terms_used.ottoman: gel-git ebru (biz ile çekilmiş S-dalga deseni)
terms_used.english: Gel-git ebru ('come-go' marbling): a marbling subtype produced by drawing a single stylus (biz) back and forth through the pigment-covered size in alternating directions, creating flowing organic S-curves. Distinct from taraklı ebru (combed with a multi-tooth comb). Confirmed on p008 of this album.

Vassale: a mounting technique in which the calligraphy (or painting) is written on a separate sheet of paper, which is then affixed to a window cut in the larger decorated paper ground. The text panel appears to float in a window within the ebru margin. Visible as a clear seam at the panel edge in IIIF images.

Altın cetvelli: a framing system of gold ruling lines applied around the calligraphy panel. In this album, a consistent multi-line system is used throughout: typically three lines in gold, dark green/black, and green, forming a nested frame between the vassale-mounted panel and the outer ebru margin.

terms_used.ottoman: zerkâri / salbek kafes / yaldızlı kafes desen cilt
terms_used.english: Zerkâri: gold-worked decoration applied to a surface by stamping, pressing, or tooling. In the binding of this album, the zerkâri takes the form of a salbek kafes (diamond lattice trellis) with floral quadrilobed nodes, stamped in gold on red leather — the characteristic luxury album binding type of the late Ottoman period.

Salbek: a pendant or tongue extending from a central medallion (şemse) on a binding cover. In the context of the lattice binding, 'salbek kafes' refers to the diamond-grid pattern itself, where the term is extended to describe the lattice of interlocking diagonal lines.
Ketebe kaydı: the closing inscription in which the calligrapher records their name, and sometimes the date and place. In this album, the ketebe of Hasan Rıza appears with the date AH 1318 on p014.

bibliography.citation: Derman, M. Uğur. Letters in Gold: Ottoman Calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı Collection, Istanbul. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998.
bibliography.relevance: Primary English-language reference for the Ottoman calligraphic album tradition and the late Ottoman calligraphic school to which Hasan Rıza belonged. Covers the meşk (teaching practice) tradition, the muraqqaʿāt format, and the role of Sâmi Efendi's circle — which includes Hasan Rıza as a student — in late 19th-century Istanbul calligraphy.
bibliography.access_notes: Exhibition catalogue (Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1998). ISBN 978-0870998843. Widely held at Islamic art and Ottoman studies libraries.

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila S. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas 17 (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational taxonomic study providing the classification framework for marbled paper (ebrî / abrī) and its subtypes, including the distinction between battal ebru (stone marbling) and other marbling techniques. Blair's categorization of decorated papers in Islamic manuscripts underpins the classification of the ebru margin papers in this record.
bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed article. Available via JSTOR (Muqarnas Online). Open-access PDF accessible at Academia.edu.

bibliography.citation: Roxburgh, David J. The Persian Album, 1400–1600: From Dispersal to Collection. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Essential study of the murakkaa album format and its decorated paper programs in the Persianate-Ottoman tradition, providing the conceptual framework for understanding the muraqqaʿāt genre, the role of varied paper programs in album design, and the tradition of assembling calligraphic kıtʿa within decorated borders. Relevant for contextualizing the Ottoman late-period continuation of this tradition in yb_02788.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; widely held at research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Çağman, Filiz, and Zeren Tanındı. The Topkapı Saray Museum: The Albums and Illustrated Manuscripts. Translated and edited by J. M. Rogers. Boston: Little, Brown, 1986.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Ottoman calligraphic albums and their decorated paper programs, providing comparative context for the murakkaat format and the role of varied ebru margin papers in late Ottoman album production. Relevant for the zerkâri binding type and multi-panel album structure observed in yb_02788.
bibliography.access_notes: Exhibition catalogue; widely held at Turkish and Islamic art research libraries.

bibliography.citation: Bloom, Jonathan M. Paper Before Print: The History and Impact of Paper in the Islamic World. New Haven: Yale University Press, 2001.
bibliography.relevance: Comprehensive history of paper production and use in the Islamic world, providing material-culture background for marbled paper (ebru / abrī) production techniques and the role of decorated papers in luxury Ottoman manuscript and album production. Relevant for the battal ebru and gel-git ebru techniques documented in this album.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers. Leiden: Brill, 2009.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Islamic manuscript codicological terminology, relevant for the identification and description of the sülüs, nesih scripts, the meşk album format, the huruf mufradāt content, and the ketebe inscription in this record.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. Islamic Codicology: An Introduction to the Study of Manuscripts in Arabic Script. Translated by Deke Dusinberre and David Radzinowicz. London: Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Foundation, 2005.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational reference for Islamic manuscript codicology, covering paper decoration types, binding forms, ruling systems, and physical manuscript description — the classification framework underlying this catalog record.

bibliography.citation: Scheper, Karin. The Technique of Islamic Bookbinding: Methods, Materials and Regional Varieties. Leiden: Brill, 2015.
bibliography.relevance: Systematic study of Islamic bookbinding techniques, relevant for the physical analysis of the red leather binding with gold lattice zerkâri (salbek kafes) pattern. The late Ottoman luxury album binding type documented in yb_02788 is within the scope of Scheper's regional and chronological survey.
bibliography.access_notes: Monograph; available at Islamic bookbinding and manuscript studies libraries.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Bibliophile Aghas (Eunuchs) at Topkapı Saray.' Muqarnas 21 (2004): 333–43.
bibliography.relevance: Documents album-collecting practices at the Ottoman court and provides context for the murakkaʿāt album format as a high-status object of patronage and collection in the late Ottoman period. Relevant for situating the Hasan Rıza albums within the broader tradition of Ottoman calligraphic album production and collection.
bibliography.access_notes: Peer-reviewed article. Available via JSTOR and institutional library access.

suggested_collections.institution: Türk ve İslam Eserleri Müzesi (TIEM), Istanbul
suggested_collections.reason: The TIEM murakkaʿāt corpus (93 albums) includes several Hasan Rıza and late Ottoman meşk albums with ebru margin programs. TIEM 02471, 02482, 02649, and others provide direct comparanda for the mixed-ebru calligraphic album format.

Holds major holdings of late Ottoman calligraphic albums by Sâmi Efendi's circle, including students such as Hasan Rıza. Physical comparison with Topkapı Hasan Rıza albums would confirm attribution and contextualise the paired album format.
Major collection of Ottoman calligraphic albums with varied decorated paper programs from the late Ottoman period. Provides international comparanda for the mixed-ebru margin approach.

provenance.notes: Held at Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi under the Yazma Bağışlar (Donated Manuscripts) Koleksiyonu, shelfmark 02788. YEK ID: 346285. IIIF ID: 0000000335705. Catalogued by Halil İbrahim Salman. The Yazma Bağışlar collection comprises manuscripts donated to the Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi by private individuals and institutions; the specific donor and donation date for this album are not recorded in the YEK catalogue entry. The album is the larger companion of a matched pair with yb_02787 (shelfmark 02787, YEK ID 346284). The closely adjacent shelfmarks (02787 and 02788) suggest the two volumes were catalogued consecutively, probably as part of the same donation.

analysis_metadata.image_source: YEK Portal IIIF images, Süleymaniye Kütüphanesi — Yazma Bağışlar Koleksiyonu, YEK ID 346285, IIIF ID 0000000335705. 7 of 21 pages downloaded and examined at IIIF resolution (2592×1944 px). Visual confirmation verdict file: catalog/searches/visual_tier2h_yb_02788.json.
analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: IIIF resolution (2592×1944 px for a 310×250 mm album page) is moderate — adequate for ebru subtype identification and palette discrimination, but fine cedvel line detail and any possible zerefşân elements (such as the gold speckling noted on p021) would benefit from higher-resolution imaging. The gel-git pattern on p008 is clearly legible at this resolution. No major image quality issues noted.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: 14 of 21 pages not examined: pp004, pp005, pp006, pp007, pp009, pp010, pp011, pp012, pp013, pp015, pp016, pp017, pp019, pp020. These pages almost certainly contain additional distinct ebru palettes given the album's varied-palette design philosophy. Full coverage download recommended for complete documentation.
analysis_metadata.corpus_priority: Medium-high. The mixed-ebru program with minimum 5 distinct palettes and 2 subtypes (battal + gel-git) across a single 10-leaf album is exceptional in the corpus. The matched pair relationship with yb_02787 (sharing identical binding and endpaper) is a significant finding for understanding late Ottoman album production as coordinated sets. Priority follow-up: (1) download all remaining 14 pages to document complete ebru palette sequence; (2) physical examination of p021 gold/yellow speckling to confirm whether metallic element is present in the marbling; (3) verify YEK classification correction from 012 to 740.
